I think it’s about time some of the people in this train compartment gave some account of themselves. Or as good an account as they’re able.
What do you mean by that?
I mean that some people are so ignorant of their origins that it’s better to consult more authoritative sources. Right, let’s give it a go, shall we? Toby.

Well, I told you some of it already, Doctor. First and foremost I am an entertainer. That was my profession, before I retired. I performed before the paying public. But you can read about all that in my memoirs.
And what about the part of your story that didn’t make it into the final draft?
Ah. Well, that’s much more complex, and I’m afraid that if I spell it out, I’m going to make myself sound ridiculous.
Try me.

You’re an educated man, Doctor. You must know that sometimes Time can go wrong. Truffle around in it too much and you start disturbing things. And that’s what’s happened here. Somebody has muddied history so that you can no longer see who’s supposed to be in charge.
I once knew a lizard with very similar views. Someone tried to lock him up in an airing cupboard. It all ended in tears.

Hopeless, isn’t it, Doctor? Toby’s sense of who he is and where he comes from has been deduced from a reel of kinematic film, the record of a pioneering scientific project. He might as well have attempted to suck his biography out of this madeleine.
Eat it if you like, Inspector.
Perhaps I shall.
What do you make of all this, Miss Bultitude?
Me? Well, I've seen Toby’s film. Wasn’t a patch on Rescued by Rover.
Perhaps this will help you decide.
That is a private document. How did you get it? The hotel was supposed to send that on.

Your suitcase fell open and, well, there it was. The diary of a Doctor Alphonse Chardalot. Makes interesting reading. Not just because of what’s written in it, but how it’s written. Every few years or so, the handwriting becomes utterly illegible. It’s as if every few years the author forgets how to write, and has to relearn from scratch. This page, for instance, is a perfectly sensible write-up of an experiment. Aim, to teach a pig how to use asparagus tongs.
Heavens!
The next page, however, is just a lot of scrawl. Look. What do you make of that, Miss Bultitude?
Ais for apple. B is for ball. C is for swill.
(laughs) Oh dear. Something’s gone wrong there, hasn't it?
Oh, I thought you weren’t hungry, Inspector, but I see I’m obliged to return to the buffet car and order some more of those little cakes.
So, what do you know about Toby's life before you met him?
Not a great deal. He always said he was born in Essex. The Garden of England, he calls it. His parents were apple growers.
Note to the non-British — that would be Kent, actually.
But what were his parents like? Were they pigs?
They looked like him, yes. He always says that in Essex that didn’t matter so much.
What made him leave home?

Why do any of us leave home? He wanted to work, he wanted to make his own way in the world. He went to London, walked there from his parents’ orchard. He was looking for work as a kitchen porter at the Royal East London Hospital, wnen a showman spotted him on the street. That was Tom Norman. Perhaps you’ve heard of him? From a very old and respected circus family. Anyway, this showman was in need of new talent. His old partner had just left for a tour of the Low Countries.
What did he have to do?

Oh, nothing much. Talk to the audience, tell them something of his life and experiences, sing a little aria or two. He loved it. And he was particularly keen on that little book. I think he and the showman cooked it up together. Who knows whether any of it was true. I certainly never believed the bit about his heroic rescue of a baby from the spire of Chesterfield Cathedral. What would a baby be doing up the top of a cathedral?
(Note — the spire of St Mary and All Saints is highly distinctive, but it isn’t on a cathedral, just a parish church.)
But he believed all this, right?

Well, yes, I think he did. He has always had a little difficulty distinguishing fiction and reality. I read him something from the newspaper on a Monday, and he tells it back to me on a Wednesday, claiming it happened to him during his schooldays. He never even went to school. That’s why I never took all this stuff about assassination very seriously. Just thought it was one of his whims, one of his quirks. I do hope he’s not come to any harm. I don’t know what I'd do.
And then I met Nurse Albertine - she answered my advertisement in The Lady — and stayed with me after I decided to give up touring.
Oh, is that the time?
What a lovely pocket watch, Inspector. May I?
No you may not.
Anyway, Toby, why did you give up touring?
Became too dangerous.
How so?
Perhaps you’d better ask the Inspector.
As if I'd remember. You saw to that, Toby.
We were simply protecting ourselves.
Oh, I see. You gave him a sharp jab with your cattle-prod when he caught up with you.
That's right.
And you’re aware, I assume, that the technology required to power that device ought not to exist on this planet in this time.
Yes.
Does that help explain how you know the future?
It might. I’ve been around a bit.
You’ve travelled in time?
No, not exactly.
Don’t talk in riddles, Toby.
Look, I don’t know why you keep on at me. It makes perfect sense to me.
Of course it does, but to the rest of us it’s a lot of mangled nonsense.
Let’s see if you do any better, eh, Inspector? You’re a scientist, are you?
Of course.
What sort?
What would you like?
Am I the only one here who knows his own life story?
At last. Something that isn’t a cow or a dyke. And it has hills, too.
And it has a little statue of a peeing boy.
Pity we’re not here for fun.
What’s it saying?
The time machine has been switched on.
Is it yours?

No, it’s not. That marker is still static on the screen, but the new one’s moving real fast. We're going to have company when we get to town. Wonder where it’s homing in on? Let’s have a look at this thing.
How ingenious.
You know that street?
We’re not far away. Place de Brouckére. It’s right by the Hotel Metropole. We stayed there during Toby’s last European tour.
Drive on, then.

The experiments were long and complex. I worked into the night. I scarcely ate. I slept at my bench, toiling over my test subjects. There were many failures, but then my two boys, Charlie and Toby, they took. They really took. They grew in their little bell jars until they were smiling back at me through the glass. Then I decided to allow them to take their first halting steps into the world.
Could you pass the mayonnaise please, Miss Bultitude?
Of course.
Are you eating that paté?
No, I’m not very hungry.
May I?
Of course.
So what happened after you let them out?
They went snuffling about the laboratory, grubbing apple cores out of the waste paper basket, chewing up my box files. You know what piglets are. But I soon taught them a few manners.
What happened to Charlie?
Pneumonia. They put him in a box of shredded newspaper and gave him a little flask of charcoal, fed him warm milk from a pipette.
Did he live?
I don’t believe so.
Believe, Inspector?
It seems so long ago now.
Why are you listening to this, Doctor? The man’s insane.
Then humour him.
Why should I?
How sharper than the serpent’s tooth it is.
Then pass me those sandwiches, Doctor, would you?
Touch those boys and you'll regret it.

I have a theory about your experimental work, Inspector. Someone created Toby, but I don’t think it was you. Toby’s well-preserved, I know, but don’t let his skill with a make-up box fool you. He’s a good ten years older than you. Did you study arithmetic as well as biology?
I won't listen to this, Doctor.

But have you ever considered the evidence properly? I would have thought the explanation would have been obvious to the man who triumphed in the case of the murderess of Saint Germain. Being in possession of a man’s diary doesn’t make you that man, you know. I think the real Chardalot died years ago,
don’t you? He was a time traveller, wasn’t he? And through him you and Toby have gained the odd bit of garbled foreknowledge. But you’re no more the real Chardalot than I am.
Nonsense.
Did you create Toby? Or did someone else create you both?
Impossible!
What happened to the real Chardalot? Did he abandon you in this time and place, or did you take against him and eat him for lunch?
Doctor, this is beneath you. Take your trotters off that fruit cake, boy!
Don’t speak to him like that!
Put that cake down.
Look, I’ve had just about enough of you. I shall eat it if I wish. Now look what you’ve done! Kicking over the trolley in a fit of temper. The Doctor paid for that, you know.
Actually, I didn’t.

Do you remember none of your lessons, Toby? Do you not remember how I taught you to be a gentleman? To hold your knife and fork correctly? To leave a little on your plate so as not to offend your hosts? To wait until food is passed to you. Are you a boy or a pig, huh?
Doctor, we should have him thrown off the train.
Try me, boy.
Toby, sit down. Don’t rise to it.
That’s right, boy. Be a man.
I'll do better than that.
Don’t do anything stupid, Toby. Let go of the Inspector. Close the carriage door and let him walk back to us.
You just don’t know when to stop, do you, Inspector? You drive a man to murder!
Sorry. Don’t understand. It just sounds like oinking to me. Now sit down and be a sensible piglet.
Toby, be careful.

I’m stronger than you, boy. Look, you think you have the muscle to push me through that door, but see, I can move my hand like this, reach down to my waistcoat, and look at my watch as if I was leaning on a breakwater at Ostend, enjoying the sunshine.
We'll see about that.
Toby, don’t!
Chardalot screams. Door closes.
Toby, are you all right?
I think so.
Toby.
Look, I’m sorry, Doctor, but he deserved it. It was him or me, and that was a cleaner death than going under the vivisectionist’s knife.
If only it were that simple. Did you not see what he took out of his pocket?
A fob watch.
Why on Earth would a man hanging from a train carriage want to know the time? That wasn’t a fob watch, it was a parachute.
Nice hotel, the Metropole. You don’t like roughing it, you and Toby.
Nothing more than we deserve. Is there a house number on that little machine?
Basement flat number 12. Nice window boxes. Wouldn’t have had him down as a tulip man.
So, how do we break in?
Let’s establish whether anyone’s at home.
Ah. Shall 1?
Why not.
Door bell rings.
How long should we wait?
Door opens.
Oh. Toby.
You mistake me, madame. I am only the butler.
UNDER-BUTLER: (Irish) And I am only the under-butler.
You look very familiar.
I do hope not, madame. Familiarity in our profession would be considered a sacking offence.
We have an appointment with your master. I assume he telegraphed to inform you of our arrival.
UNDER-BUTLER: He did, madame.
Oh, er, well, you’d better let us in, then, hadn’t you.
Of course, madame. Madame.
UNDER-BUTLER: May I take madame’s coat?
I don’t have one, I’m afraid.
No matter. Madame can have this one. I'll hang it up for you.
Thank you.
UNDER-BUTLER: Now, would madame please step into the drawing room.
And madame.
Oh, of course.
Would the ladies care for an aperitif?
Now you’re talking.
UNDER-BUTLER: A Campari, perhaps?
Yeah.
With a little soda?
Let’s go mad.
UNDER-BUTLER: Do be seated.
You could drown someone in these armchairs.
If you wanted to.
Madame.
UNDER-BUTLER: Madame.
Bottom’s up.
And nibbles, too.
Devils on horseback, madame? Miniature blini, salted cashew?
Well, gesundheit.
Here’s mud in your eye.
Postman brought you something nice?
Sorry, madame?
Interesting looking packing case in the corner there. What is it, a bathing hut?
It wouldn’t be a large wooden box with a lamp on top, would it?
That would depend, madame, on the position of the observer. For my part, I would describe it as a multidimensional travel capsule for surfing the loops of the time spiral.
UNDER-BUTLER: Or as I heard our employer describe it scant moments ago, this week’s best chance out of 1913.
You mean he’s here already?
He returned just before you knocked on the door.
Oh no!

I'll pretend I didn’t hear that, Nurse Albertine. So sorry to have kept you. Oh dear, you don’t look very pleased to see me. Miss Brown, you appear to be about to vomit into the nut dish. I would have hoped for a more fulsome welcome from a lady who once kissed me on the beach at Ostend.
What does a man’s suitcase say about him?
Not where he lives. Not in this case, unfortunately. You’d think he would have put a label on the inside lining. Most irresponsible.
What have we got? A couple of back-numbers of the Police Gazette. Lovely illustrations.
Oh, I remember that chap. Drowned his wife in the bath and then went into the next room and played Nearer My God To Thee on the harmonium.
And what's in that paper package?
Butter biscuits.
Oh. May I?
If you hurry. We’re here.
What are we going to do? How are we to find him again?
I think I’ve just stopped worrying about that, Miss Bultitude. Look over there on the platform. The man with the cardboard placard and the bowler hat.
Oh. Chardalot and party.
Splendid. That'll be us, then.
Now, ladies, what are you drinking?
Campari and soda.
Marvellous. May I join you? I’ve had quite a day. Not too much ice.
What happened to you?
Oh, just a little accident.
You ought to let me help you, Inspector. You’re more badly injured than you imagine.
Don't give it a moment’s thought, Nurse Albertine. I'll sort myself out when our little party is concluded. I’d hate to be an inattentive host. Now, isn’t this nice?
Might I ask you something about your butlers, Inspector?
What about them?
Are they clones?
Eh? What do you mean?
Clones. Genetic copies.
Genetic? I’m sorry, I must have been away for that. Think of them as rough sketches. Now Toby, he’s my masterpiece.
What branch of science did you study, Inspector?
Science.
Where?
At university. At Combray, on the planet Gamantis.
Combray? Are you sure about that?

Of course. I took a room in the old hostelry of the Oiseaux Fleché, from whose windows and the pavement a smell used to rise of cooking which rises still in my mind now and then, in the same warm gusts of comfort.
Nostalgic for it, are you?
Of course.
Then why don’t you go back there and leave us all alone!
If only it was so easy.
You arrived before us. You don’t exactly travel by motor car, do you?

No. Look at this. One of my few keep-sakes from home. Wonderful craftsmanship. The filigree work, the astronomical dial. But looks aren’t everything, you know. This device only allows me short gads through time and space. It has a range of about four hundred kilometres and two hours, and it will only take one passenger. Fine if you want to catch this afternoon’s performance of Hello Tango at the London Hippodrome, all alone. Completely useless if you want to take a sapient pig to a scientific conference on the planet Gamantis some half a century hence. Which, by a stroke of bad luck, is exactly what I need to do. (coughs) Do excuse me.

Inspector, I think you’ve broken most of your ribs. You have a gash in your neck which is releasing a little trickle of Campari, your speech has begun to slur. I’d urge you to let me look at these wounds.

Yes, it was a rough do, wasn’t it? I’m afraid I was obliged to operate this device while falling from the open door of the express train from Ostend to Brussels. I think I bounced from the tunnel wall before the little thing kicked into action.
What happened?
Spot of bother with some livestock. Nothing that need trouble you.
You mean Toby. Is Toby all right?
Probably in the buffet car licking under the lid of a jam pot as we speak.
But he’s not injured.
No. In fact, my unscheduled arrival here was a consequence of my attempt to protect him from harm. He went for my neck, do you see? Forced me to bail out early.
You must be pretty sore about that. You’ve been after him all these years.
Oh, but I didn’t have the Doctor then. I’m sure he can be relied upon to shepherd Toby to this very room. I’m expecting a reunion quite soon.
And in the meantime you’re just gonna bleed onto the upholstery?
Aren’t you in terrible pain?

We Gamantes don’t really feel pain. I believe we bred out most of our animal weaknesses centuries ago. I know that I am not in any real danger for another couple of hours at least, which is why I decided to join you for cocktails. Chin-chin. Oops. I’m still leaking. So sorry. Look, can’t we just have a normal conversation? Act like ladies and gentlemen?
Okay. Why don’t we talk about your diary?
Not you too. I am a scientist. I conduct experiments. I do things with alembics and syringes and Bunsen burners.
How do you know you’re not just an experimental subject who got above himself and learned to drink Campari?
Well, Miss Brown, I think we can squash that theory right away. The operating theatre awaits. If you will just let me drink up. Thank you. Gentlemen?
Sir?
UNDER-BUTLER: Sir.
I think it’s time you scrubbed up, don’t you?
In a motor car.
Do you know this city well? I’m not sure I’ve been here yet. I remember coming to buy an engagement ring once, but all this had gone by then.
An engagement ring? Who was the lucky lady?
Oh, it was business, not pleasure, I’m afraid.
I know it. I played the Opera House in ’92, 94 and ’97. Lovely dressing rooms.
Can’t we get this man to go any faster?
Oh, cabbie? Double the fare if we reach our destination in the next ten minutes.
Oh! Good work, Doctor.
Ah, thank you, yes, but has anyone got any cash on them?
I can cover the expense, but I do wish you hadn’t said that to the driver.
Why not?
Because we’re here already.
Welcome to my little treatment room, ladies. Sorry for the mess. We’ve only just moved in.
You don’t travel light, do you.
If I have the means to bring my possessions with me, why should I leave them behind? Look, I’ve even kept a box of Toby’s toys. How he loved that kaleidoscope.
Did he read these books too?
That one was his favourite. Feel free to browse, Miss Brown.
Sir, we are ready to begin.
Avert your eyes, ladies. I’m just going to slip into the surgical gown.
You’d better get a move on.

Yes, you're right, I am beginning to feel rather unwell. But time is still on my side, so I'll just lay back on the operating table and let my servants get hacking away with their saws and scissors, eh?
You’re not going to have any gas?
I do not feel pain. Now, turn that monitor my way, would you?
Of course, sir.
Ah, the right kidney will need replacing. Fortunately I have plenty in the bank. Go and fetch one from the cold store, would you?
UNDER-BUTLER: At once, sir.

They've not had to dig as deep as this for oh, well, a long time. It’s hard to remember. However, the old skills never die. In an hour or so they’ll have done their work and I'll be up and joking with the nurses.
No surgeon would operate on a patient without knowing their medical history. Are you sure you know yours, Inspector? Are you sure you’re gonna get this right?
UNDER-BUTLER: One kidney, sir, dressed to the right.
That doesn’t look good to me. Is that really a human kidney?

Look, I Know what you're driving at, Nurse Albertine, and it must stop. I am aman, a human man. I had a mother and father. They lived in a little cottage with roses around the door. I remember the day I left home. I remember my mother pressing a peppermint into my hand and wishing me luck.
Because you were going to London to seek your fortune? Those are Toby’s memories, not yours. Or are they nobody’s?
Enough of this. We'll see who’s the pig and who’s the man.
UNDER-BUTLER: Here’s the relevant organ, sir. We’re ready to begin.
Sounds like we might have visitors already, Inspector.
He is nippy, isn’t he, your friend the Doctor. Let’s draw the security curtains.
Sir.
An electrical barrier has now fallen around the operating table. It will be quite impossible for you to interfere without my consent.
A forcefield, is it?
Probably. Make the first incision.
Immediately, sir.
Not like that, you idiot. You’re going to kill him.
Nonsense. Do you hear anything irregular from these monitors? No, so keep your place.
I don’t think your staff are qualified to carry out this operation, Inspector. Let them do it and you will die on that table.
I'd listen to her, if I were you. It’s good advice.
Good evening, Doctor, Miss Bultitude, boy. You'll excuse me if I don’t get up.
Doctor, those things. They’re versions of me.
Give the pig a toffee apple.
Save your strength, Inspector. You’re in a bad way. You pulled the rip-cord a bit too late, didn’t you?

You’re right. But once I’ve been patched up I'll be in a very advantageous position, won’t I? I have your space-time machine, Doctor, and I have Toby. Nurse Albertine no longer possesses her ray gun, and I have the means to detain you all in this house. I’d say I have the winning hand.
You might, unless one of those creatures chops it off.
They know how to follow technical procedure. Oh. Suddenly I feel very strange.
What happens if something goes wrong? Why take the risk?
I have every confidence in my employees.
Maybe you should, if you’re asking them to slice lemons for you, but look at the way he’s holding that scalpel. He’s no idea of what he’s doing.
Oh, I can’t watch this. I’m going outside.
Quite impossible, Miss Bultitude. All the external doors have been sealed. You'll just have to put a paper bag over your head.
I have an empty toffee bag.
Toby, you can’t have eaten since you got down from the train. Feeling hungry?
A little.
There may be a dusty old box of liquorish comfits in that tea chest there, or sugared almonds, or some such.
I won’t eat them if they smell poisoned, you know.
You see, I can be an indulgent father. Have a sweetie, boy. Call me Daddy and have a sweetie.
You have quite an archive there, Inspector.

My kaleidoscope, and that dear little train set. That book. I love that book. A story about a pig who goes away from his parents, to war or to market or somewhere. But the illustration isn’t quite as I remember it.
Should I continue, sir?
You’re fine surgeons. I trained you both myself, didn’t I?
UNDER-BUTLER: As you say, sir.
Can anyone smell baking? Is somebody making gingerbread?

Inspector, please. These two creatures are your butlers. Of course they’re not going to contradict you. Will you allow them to hack you to pieces just because of your pride? There’s no need to replace that kidney. You'll do just fine without it.
But I’ve always had two.

You know nothing about human physiology, do you. Listen, I’ll do the work for you. I'll make it better. Inspector, I love Toby, and you are like Toby in some way. I don’t know how but you are. Give me the needle and thread, give me the plaster of Paris, and send those butchers away.
Albertine, you’d help him, and you love me? You love me and you’d help him?
A man is dying. Don’t you care?
I don’t know. I feel as if someone were about to tear me to pieces. This picture, Albertine. This picture.

I think we should all take a look. I'll hold it up, Inspector, so you can see. The little cottage with the roses around the door, the bees going from flower to flower. See who’s standing in the doorway. Two pigs, one in a waistcoat, one in an apron.
Mummy and Daddy.
I wish it was true, Inspector. I really do. And look here, what do you see, hmm? Who are these figures waving goodbye to?
It’s hard to see.
Tell him, Toby.
Two little piglets, at the garden gate, with little knapsacks. There are little tears rolling down their cheeks.

This is your past, Toby, and it’s yours too, Inspector. But it never happened. Just a shared dream about a watercolour painting, a story you told yourselves, you and Toby, when you were children, when someone, some madman, some deranged doctor kept you in a lab like this.
I don’t... I don’t understand.

Of course you don’t. You and Toby have pieced together the evidence and you’ve got it wrong. You’ve truffled through the personal effects of the man who made you, whoever he was, you’ve taken his scientific notes and his alien gadgets and his clothes and his books, and you’ve been play-acting with them ever since.
But I was born in Essex! I ran away to go on the stage!
You were born in one of the test tubes in this lab, Toby. You did go on the stage, but the rest is in that picture book. And as for all that stuff about evolution having taken the wrong course...
And what about him?
I am from Gamantis. I am one of the Gamantes.
No, you're not, Inspector. The Gamantes. The Guermantes. And who are the Guermantes, Peri?
They’re in Proust. They live in a castle at Combray. The narrator idolises the family, wants to be part of it, but he never will.

Your creator did his work well. I can’t be very sure of his sanity or his morals, but he achieved what he wanted. He came here from some other world - not Gamantis, there’s no such place as Gamantis — but wherever he came from and whatever his motives, he did something extraordinary. He brought two boys

into the world. And his boys have really made something of themselves. One went on the stage, had a wonderful career, fell in love. The other, little Charlie, the younger and more confused of the pair, well, it’s harder to say what he’s been up to. Trying and failing to continue his creator’s work, making notes in his creator’s note book, driving himself half-mad in the attempt to maintain the illusion of his own history. But I’m sure it’s not too late for him to reform. What do you think, Inspector?
I... I’m not feeling very well. I can’t see the room.

We were both under the knife. I thought it was just me, but you must have been there too, in that pen, sleeping in straw, sitting up at the dinner table with a rap over the knuckles with a ruler if you slurped your soup. You're not my father, Inspector. You’re not my tormentor. You’re my brother. You must have been there at my side. Come back to it now. Make those creatures put down the knives.
Very well. You heard. Stand down.
We shall desist, sir. And might I suggest that my colleague and I prepare some light refreshments?
Do it. Lower the security curtain. And find some of those little biscuits for our guests.
Right, Doctor, are you going to stand there gawping or are you going to get some soap and offer me some help? This man’s life is in our hands.
The orchards of England, how I remember them.
Do you remember them?
Well, to be honest, no. But they’re jolly nice, all the same.
Here we are. Chauffoir chicken garnished with crayfish and stoned cherries.
Miss Bultitude, you are an excellent cook.
Yes, I am. Just as well, isn’t it? Well, it’s all ready. Someone had better fetch the Doctor.
I'll go and get him. He’s just reading his book by the summer house
Can we start?
No. Not until we’re all sitting together. We have an announcement to make.
Oh yes.
So, you've finished it, then
Yes. It didn’t really spoil the ending, you know, what you said about him being hit by a car.
I’m not that mean.
He’s a difficult man to spend six volumes with, though, isn’t he? Particularly when he spends so much of them fixating on an idea that turns out to be a waste of time.
And full of nostalgia for something that you suspect may never really have existed.
Distant laughter.
Well, nostalgia’s not a terminal condition. In pigs, at least.
What about pigs with a history of impersonating officers?
Yes, I wonder what he’s doing?
I don’t know. Maybe he'll do what he said, apply for a position with the detective police. There’d be something fitting about him doing it for real when he’s lied about it for so long.

I suppose in time he might come to visit his brother. But he might just stay hidden. Why let horrible facts get in the way of a sustaining fantasy? I almost hope neither of them ever discovers the whole truth about their childhood.
I guess. What good would it do them? Who wants to know that they should never have been born?

Oh, I don’t think there’s any danger of them finding out too much. Whoever conducted the experiments to produce Toby and Charlie, their secrets died with them. They weren't from this time or this planet, but beyond that it’s impossible to say. I think it’s best if it remains that way.
That lot seem happy enough, don’t they?
Miss Bultitude has her idol living in her spare room.
I only hope Albertine can stand the competition.
Do you think it might be time to er...
Slip away? Probably, yes.
The delivery men left the Tardis at the back gate.
So, shall we?
Lets.
Doctor! Peri!
They’re not here.
Do you think...
The Tardis is dematerialising in the distance.
I suppose that settles the question.
He’s left his book behind.
Oh yes.
Time Regained.
What's it like?
Tearing paper, chewing.
Not bad, but it might taste better with a little vinaigrette.

ALBERTINE: Well, that makes things more complicated.
DOCTOR: What does?
ALBERTINE: The receptionist says he saw Inspector Chardalot go up the stairs about a minute ago.
DOCTOR: Alone?
ALBERTINE: Alone.
DOCTOR: Listen, then. I'll go to the steam bath and you take a look upstairs. Be careful, though. Just establish whether the Inspector’s in his suite or not. Room 312. Then meet me back here.
ALBERTINE: Right.
DOCTOR: Oh, hang on. Where is this Turkish Steam Bath?
ALBERTINE: Turn right down that corridor, right at the end, left through the double doors with the stained glass elephants, then follow the smell of stale sweat until you reach the door marked Mens Sana In Corpore Sano. You know what that means, don’t you?
DOCTOR: Something about the men’s sauna offering corporal punishment. See you back here as soon as.
ALICE: So that’s one julienne soup, one marzipan tart, a brace of roasted quail, one pumpernickel and six bottles of Kulmbacher. Is that everything?
TOBY: All that comes to mind at the moment.
ALICE: That’s everything. Thank you. (phone down)
TOBY: How dare he.
ALICE: Don’t fuss about it, Toby.
TOBY: Well, to leave like that. And just before tea time, too.
ALICE: We can still have our fun.
TOBY: I suppose.
ALICE: Are you nearly ready?
TOBY: Ready. Draw the curtains, would you?
ALICE: All set.
TOBY: One very important element, Miss Bultitude. That heart-shaped box on top of the ottoman. Open it up.
ALICE: It looks splendid. Praline?
TOBY: Caramel.
ALICE: Oh, capital. I do love the flickers.
TOBY: Let’s start the show.
ALICE: That’s Vienna, surely?
TOBY: Mmm, Vienna. Vienna in the summer of 1903. The capital of porcine culture. Freud worked here during this period, you know, in his consulting rooms on the Berggasse. All the finest minds in the world were there. Schopenhauer, Nietzsche, Strindberg. They were all pigs, you see.
ALICE: Oh.
TOBY: Strindberg went in search of the Philosopher’s Stone, did you know that?
ALICE: Did he find it?
TOBY: No.
ALICE: Pity. It might have made him nicer to his wife.
TOBY: Look, here’s Sir Henry Irving performing Hamlet’s famous soliloquy. Oh that the Everlasting should set its canon ‘gainst self-slaughter. To die, to eat, to eat, perchance to lunch.
ALICE: Oh, I don’t think that’s right.
TOBY: I forget the exact words. Ah, here’s Colonel Dreyfus. A scandal, you know, and a warning from history.
ALICE: You know, Toby, I have something to confess to you. Have you ever been to Madame Ensor’s curiosity shop?
TOBY: No.
ALICE: Well, I don’t blame you, frankly. It’s packed to the rafters with the most grotesque tat. Taxidermy. And she keeps a monkey that’s always relieving itself in to the Nautilus shells.
TOBY: Why are you telling me this?
ALICE: I have a weakness for taxidermy. It all started on my fifth birthday when my step-father bought me my first python attacking a mongoose.
TOBY: Why did he do a thing like that?
